introduction.p: A pairing of vectors is called a (real) inner product if it satisfies the four axioms below.

statement.p: Convince yourself that the pairing \uvecinprod{v}{w} = \udotprod{v}{w} satisfies the inner product axioms.

introduction.p: Consider the pairing \inprod{p}{q} = p(-1)q(-1) + p(0)q(0) + p(1)q(1) on \poly_2(\R), the space of all polynomials of degree 2 or less.

task.p: For each of Axiom RIP, Axiom RIP, and Axiom RIP, rewrite the left- and right-hand sides of the axiom equality using definition of the given pairing.
By comparing left- and right-hand sides, convince yourself that the pairing will satisfy each of those axioms.

task.p: Would Axiom RIP hold if we used this pairing on \poly_3(\R), the space of all polynomials of degree 3 or less?
If not, how would you fix it?

activity.p: Combining Axiom RIP, and Axiom RIP, we can say that an inner product is linear in the first term: \inprod{a \uvec{u} + b \uvec{v}}{\uvec{w}} = a \uvecinprod{u}{w} + b \uvecinprod{v}{w} . Must an inner product also be linear in the second term?
Use Axiom RIP for a special choice of k to determine that an inner product must satisfy \inprod{\zerovec}{\uvec{v}} = 0 for every vector \uvec{v} in the vector space.

task.p: Compute the dot product \udotprod{w}{w} for the \C^2 vector \uvec{w} = (\ci,\ci). Is this going to work out for us, given the geometric reason for including Axiom RIP in our list axioms that we explored in ?

statement.p: Let's back up a dimension. We already know how to compute length in \C^1, by regarding complex numbers as vectors in the complex plane. Use this point of view to propose a pairing on \C^1 that will satisfy Axiom RIP. (Make sure to define your pairing as a pairing of two possibly different \C^1 vectors.)

prelude.p: The dot product is not the only inner product on \R^n.

introduction.p: Recall that the dot product on \R^n can be realized using matrix multiplication: \udotprod{v}{w} = \utrans{\uvec{w}} \uvec{v} . (See .)

Let's investigate using vectors in \R^2 and a 2 \times 2 matrix A = \begin{bmatrix} a \amp b \\ c \amp d \end{bmatrix} . Recall that \uvec{e}_1,\uvec{e}_2 represent the standard basis vectors in \R^2.

task.p: What does using \uvec{e}_1,\uvec{e}_2 in Axiom RIP tell you about b and c, if the axiom is going to be true for pairing ? What does this say about A?
What does using \uvec{e}_1 and \uvec{e}_2 (separately) in Axiom RIP say about a and d, if the axiom is going to be true for pairing ?
Calculate \uvecinprod{x}{x} for \uvec{x} = (d,-b). After simplifying, you should find \det A hiding in the result.
If Axiom RIP is to be true, what does \uvecinprod{x}{x} for this \uvec{x} tell you about \det A?
